author: By Anna Kodé
title: Is It an Art Gallery or a Living Space? Actually, It’s Both.
description: At Maison Lune, in Los Angeles, you may forget you’re in a home — until you hear the sound of the clothes dryer.
content: At first glance, Maison Lune, an art gallery in the Venice neighborhood of Los Angeles, looks exactly like a home. Yes, there are paintings and ceramics on display, but there’s also a bed, a full kitchen, a bathtub. And sometimes you can hear the tumble of laundry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Johnny Lujack, a Star Quarterback at Notre Dame, Dies at 98
description: He took the Irish to three national championships in the 1940s, won the Heisman Trophy in 1947 and then had a stellar (if brief) stint with the Chicago Bears.
content: Johnny Lujack, the celebrated Notre Dame quarterback who won the 1947 Heisman Trophy, played on three national championship teams and then starred in the N.F.L. for the Chicago Bears, died on Tuesday at a hospice facility in Naples, Fla. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: The president of Norway’s federation, a rare woman of influence in soccer, is speaking up.
description: Lise Klaveness does not pull punches. It is not her style. To some, that is a problem. To Klaveness, a former national team player who is now the president of Norway’s soccer federation, it is just who she is.
content: Lise Klaveness does not pull punches. It is not her style. To some, that is a problem. To Klaveness, a former national team player who is now the president of Norway’s soccer federation, it is just who she is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A Battle With Fire on 2 Continents, in Photos
description: Deadly blazes are raging across portions of southern Europe and North Africa, including the Greek islands and Algeria.
content: The crackling flames have left charred forests, drawing in thousands of firefighters to stop their hungry march. Residents are filling buckets of water to douse blazes in their hometowns. And tourists are huddled with their belongings, not in hotels or resorts, but in evacuation centers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: PacWest Bank, Thrashed by Deposit Crisis, Will Be Taken Over
description: Banc of California is set to absorb PacWest, a larger lender that has seen its depositors flee this year.
content: PacWest Bank, which never fully recovered from its hammering during this year’s banking crisis, will be absorbed by a smaller lender, Banc of California, the banks announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Where the Republican Candidates Stand on Border Security and Immigration
description: Support for a wall is now routine, and some presidential candidates say they would use military force to secure the border if elected.
content: The blistering immigration policy that Donald J. Trump enacted when he was in the White House shifted his party’s baseline on the issue to the right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: The Cocktail Wit Is Watered Down in a Rickety New ‘Cottage’
description: Jason Alexander directs a Broadway farce that aims for the high style of Noël Coward but falls on its face instead.
content: Farce is the emergency that keeps emerging. That’s why it depends so much on doors: to admit fresh trouble and lock it in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell, Peter Eavis, Emma Goldberg and Matthew Haag
title: Tech Firms Once Powered New York’s Economy. Now They’re Scaling Back.
description: After years of steady growth, many technology companies are laying off workers and giving up millions of square feet of office space in the city.
content: For much of the last two decades, including during the pandemic, technology companies were a bright spot in New York’s economy, adding thousands of high-paying jobs and expanding into millions of square feet of office space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dream Hampton
title: What We’re Forced to Leave Behind When It Floods
description: Dream Hampton explores water as a force of harmony and devastation as climate change affects her home city of Detroit.
content: I love the way Joan Didion wrote about place and memory. The December she died, in 2021, grief had already lodged deep in my chest after I lost my beloved friend Greg Tate. It was hard to breathe, but harder to imagine returning to Harlem, where we’d spent afternoons that equaled years, writing, talking and walking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Booksellers Move to the Front Lines of the Fight Against Book Bans in Texas
description: With a book-rating law set to take effect in September, a group of booksellers, along with publishers and authors, filed suit to argue that it is unconstitutional.
content: A group of booksellers, publishers and authors filed a lawsuit on Tuesday to stop a new law in Texas that would require stores to rate books based on sexual content, arguing the measure would violate their First Amendment rights and be all but impossible to implement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni, Robert Draper and Luke Broadwater
title: As Spending Fights Loom, Freedom Caucus Is at a Crossroads
description: The ouster of Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene from the ultraconservative group and the rise of another rebel faction have raised questions about where the real power lies on the far right.
content: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia was voting on the floor of the House on the morning of June 23 when she saw her name trending on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Dirty Pictures From a Revolution
description: Though “Minx” and “Stiffed” are set 50 years ago, the debates they present — about desire and gender and equality and autonomy — feel startlingly current.
content: On a nightclub stage, a blond woman in a sensible skirt suit runs back and forth in T-strap heels, overwhelmed by her duties to her family, her boss, herself. She stumbles, then falls. “It’s so hard being a woman in 1973,” she pouts, still sprawled. “If only there was a way to make a change.” Then the shirtless men in breakaway pants appear behind her. Women can’t have it all, now or 50 years later. An eyeful of oiled torsos, however muscular, may not have been a perfect substitute for real social transformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: How War Destroyed a ‘Long and Happy Marriage’
description: The conflict in Ukraine has split apart millions of families. The story of Andrii Shapovalov and Tetiana Shapovalova reveals how a couple’s bond can become a casualty.
content: Andrii Shapovalov, 51, and Tetiana Shapovalova, 50, had a fantastic life together. They were married nearly 30 years, raised two sons and pursued careers that meant something to them — he as a psychotherapist working with drug addicts, she as an executive at a large ice cream company. Up until last year, they were easing into a new stage of life together as empty nesters in Dnipro, an up-and-coming city in central Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Man Sentenced to 5 Years in Scheme Tied to Trump-Inspired Border Wall
description: Prosecutors said Timothy Shea and his group stole over a million dollars, spending some on jewelry, boat payments and a Trump-themed energy drink.
content: A Colorado man convicted last year of conspiring to defraud people who donated money to build the kind of border wall championed by Donald J. Trump was sentenced Tuesday to five years and three months in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and James Hill
title: A Continental Competition, All in One Neighborhood
description: Inspired by the Africa Cup of Nations, several small-scale soccer tournaments formed in the Paris region. In a working-class landing spot for immigrants, one event lets locals revel in being exceptional.
content: At the eight-minute mark of the final of the CAN 18 soccer tournament, the players on the Mauritania team score three times in rapid succession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: TikTok Introduces Text-Only Posts
description: The social media app known for its short-form videos will now allow users to create posts that contain only words, competing with Threads and Twitter.
content: TikTok users can now post text-only content, a departure for the social media app known for its short videos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and David Pierson
title: China’s Foreign Minister Is Removed After a Month of Silence
description: Qin Gang, a sometime favorite of Xi Jinping, was replaced by Wang Yi, a seasoned diplomat, leaving many unanswered questions about Qin’s fall.
content: Only five weeks ago, China’s foreign minister, Qin Gang, was at the center of an important restoration of high-level diplomacy in U.S.-China relations: He shook hands with Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken in Beijing, and accepted an invitation to visit the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon and Nate Schweber
title: Gilgo Beach Suspect’s Home Held a 279-Weapon Arsenal and a Walk-In Vault
description: Investigators have been excavating the backyard of the suspect’s home after finding “disturbances” that might be buried objects, the district attorney said.
content: Rex Heuermann, the Long Island architect charged in the Gilgo Beach serial murder case, kept 279 weapons in his rundown home, most of them in a basement vault big enough to walk into, the authorities said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Prosecutors Follow Multiple Strands as Jan. 6 Indictment Decision Looms
description: The special counsel, Jack Smith, continues to push ahead on several fronts as he assembles evidence about former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to retain power after the 2020 election.
content: Even as the special counsel, Jack Smith, appears to be edging closer toward bringing charges against former President Donald J. Trump in connection with his efforts to overturn the 2020 election, prosecutors have been continuing to investigate multiple strands of the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Blue Bird, in the East Village, Goes All-In on Cocktails With Fruits and Veggies
description: A picnic kit from Shake Shack, a branch of Fieldtrip opens in Morningside Heights and more restaurant news.
content: Jon Howard, the bar and hospitality director for Sayless Hospitality, is taking a seasonal approach to cocktails at this new bar and bistro on the edge of the East Village. Fruits and vegetables, including red and green tomatoes, peaches, mushrooms, cucumbers, carrots, onions and rhubarb figure into his culinary cocktail creations. Red heirloom tomatoes are combined with fino sherry, bianco vermouth and basil oil for the Heirloom Tomato cocktail; and cucumbers meet gin, elderflower liqueur, lemon and Lillet for the Cucumber cocktail. Mr. Howard has returned to New York after eight years doing bar work in Nashville. French aperitifs, after-dinner drinks and a zero-proof quaff made with watermelon are also on the drinks list, along with a limited choice of red, white and sparkling wines, all natural. Traditional French fare like escargots, steak tartare, salade Lyonnaise, steak frites and steak au poivre share the menu with fritto misto, beet carpaccio and lobster spaghetti. The restaurant is on two levels, with some French touches in the décor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Emile Ducke
title: With Grain in the Cross Hairs Again, So Is a Jewel of Ukraine
description: Odesa, a port city long beloved by travelers, had been largely spared the worst of the war, but that began changing this week.
content: There are no longer walls behind the main altar of the Transfiguration Cathedral, a landmark heavily damaged when Russian missiles struck the Ukrainian port city of Odesa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: Christie Brinkley, Candace Bushnell and Laurie Anderson Party in the Hamptons
description: Over the weekend, Polo Hamptons drew hundreds of people for a match and cocktail party, and the LongHouse Reserve hosted a benefit.
content: “Everybody back up!” someone called to a crowd of people surrounding the model and actress Christie Brinkley, who was standing near a neatly trimmed lawn on a sunny and hot Saturday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Big Tech Earnings Will Test Investors’ Fervor for A.I.
description: Microsoft and Alphabet will report results on Tuesday, as investors look for signs that a rally in stocks tied to artificial intelligence is justified.
content: Nasdaq futures are up on Tuesday morning, ahead of a Big Tech earnings bonanza that kicks off when Microsoft and Alphabet report second-quarter results after the closing bell. One question is at the top of many investors’ minds: Is the hype around artificial intelligence, which has propelled tech giants’ stock prices sky-high in recent months, justified, or is it another bubble in the making?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Senate Targets China, Voting to Restrict Farmland Purchases and U.S. Investment
description: Senators voted overwhelmingly to block Chinese businesses from buying farmland and mandate that American investment in the country’s national security industries be tracked.
content: The Senate on Tuesday voted overwhelmingly to block businesses based in China from purchasing farmland in the United States and place new mandates on Americans investing in the country’s national security industries, taking the first legislative steps of the new Congress to counter Beijing’s espionage activities and curtail its economic power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenn Shapland
title: The Exercise That Changed My Relationship With My Body
description: When I was diagnosed with a chronic illness in my early 20s, a local pool helped me find new ways to move.
content: In the locker room, women’s voices discuss the temperature of the air (too cold), their gardens (the weeds!), their sisters (impossible). I eavesdrop as I pull on my one-piece and flip-flops, grab my bag of toys. Blithely I bypass the lap pool; not once in my adult life have I craved more repetitive activity. Instead I set up shop on the side of the warm-water pool — foam weights, kickboard, noodle — and, slipping into the 92-degree water, I sense a holy transition. The others arrive by way of a long ramp, discarding canes or walkers, hoisting themselves from wheelchairs, fingers trailing in deepening water. It’s a runway, but no one looks at them. The Santa Fe Community College warm-water pool is not a place to be seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Sweeney
title: Is It Time to Toss My Skin Care Products?
description: Moisturizers, serums and other items degrade over time. Here’s how to know when it’s time to stop using them.
content: Q: I have a drawer full of skin care products of dubious age. Do they expire? And if so, are they still safe to use?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ingrid K. Williams
title: The Wind, the Water, the Islands: Exploring Stockholm’s Archipelago
description: For Swedes, the archipelago, consisting of more than 20,000 islands, is a quintessential summer destination. Travelers can explore it, too, by ferry and rented boat.
content: The moment the motor turned off, I was hooked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: UPS Reaches Tentative Deal With Teamsters to Head Off Strike
description: United Parcel Service faced a potential walkout by more than 325,000 union members after their five-year contract expires next week.
content: United Parcel Service announced Tuesday that it had reached a tentative deal on a five-year contract with the union representing more than 325,000 of its U.S. workers, a key step in averting a potential strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Voting by Formerly Imprisoned in Tennessee, Already Hard, Gets Harder
description: Tennessee has the nation’s second highest number of residents who remain disenfranchised because of past felony convictions.
content: Tennessee has sharply restricted the conditions under which it will restore voting rights to people who have completed prison sentences for felonies, joining a growing list of Republican-controlled states that have rolled back access to the ballot by former felons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Iowa’s Governor Will Interview G.O.P. Field, Minus One: Trump
description: Gov. Kim Reynolds next month will hold “Fair-Side Chats” with candidates including Ron DeSantis, Tim Scott and Perry Johnson, but not the former president.
content: When Gov. Kim Reynolds interviews nearly the entire Republican presidential field at the Iowa State Fair next month in a series of one-on-one chats, there will be an especially notable absence: former President Donald J. Trump, the race’s clear front-runner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Bidens’ Dog Has Bitten Several Secret Service Agents, Emails Show
description: One agent went to the hospital after being bitten by the Bidens’ German shepherd, Commander, in a series of at least 10 incidents of “aggressive behavior.”
content: One of President Biden’s dogs has bitten several Secret Service agents, and even sent one to the hospital, part of a series of at least 10 incidents of “aggressive behavior,” according to internal emails recently obtained by a conservative watchdog group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: New Zealand wants to build on ‘Fern Fever.’ Norway needs a comeback.
description: New Zealand, the World Cup’s co-host, has a chance to take another big step forward on Tuesday.
content: New Zealand, the World Cup’s co-host, has a chance to take another big step forward on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beto O'Rourke
title: Beto O’Rourke: One Person Can End Cruelty at the Border
description: If the president fails to enforce the federal government’s clear supremacy on immigration, he will allow a humanitarian crisis to grow into a political liability.
content: Gov. Greg Abbott’s escalating political stunts have killed migrants at the Texas-Mexico border. Operation Lone Star — the dangerous, illegal and ineffective border mission that Mr. Abbott has been running separately from the federal government for over two years — must be stopped. It’s time for President Biden to step up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Ashkenas
title: Not Everyone Is Against A.I. Weapons Research. Here’s Why.
description: As we face our own “Oppenheimer moment,” it’s worth looking at perspectives on A.I. that you may disagree with.
content: On Friday, I joined a crowd of popcorn-crunching neighbors to watch a late-night screening of Christopher Nolan’s “Oppenheimer.” I haven’t seen a movie theater so packed — with some polite reshuffling as ticket holders requested their assigned seats from movie hoppers who had sneaked in — since before the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: School District Woes Likened to ‘Environmental Racism’ in Flint, Mich.
description: All 13 school buildings in East Ramapo received a failing rating in a recent state-mandated survey. The New York Civil Liberties Union is calling for a state takeover.
content: Students and staff in the East Ramapo Central School District, about 30 miles north of New York City, cannot drink the tap water in any of the public school buildings, according to a new state-mandated survey, and the chronic state of disrepair has prompted calls for a takeover of the school system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Ohio Officer Is Placed on Leave After Releasing Dog on Black Truck Driver
description: Body-camera video shows a Circleville, Ohio, police officer releasing his dog on a truck driver who had his hands up after he was stopped by the Ohio State Highway Patrol.
content: An Ohio police officer was placed on leave after he was recorded on a body camera releasing his police dog on a Black truck driver who had his hands up after he was pulled over, the authorities said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Joe Manchin Is Dreaming
description: What the No Labels fantasy gets wrong about America.
content: For as long as Americans have had partisan political competition, they have hated partisanship itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israeli Reservists Threaten to Quit Over Judicial Changes, Though Few Have
description: More than 11,000 Israelis in the military reserve said last week they’d resign if the government’s judicial overhaul went ahead.
content: More than 11,000 Israelis in the military reserve said last week they’d resign if the government’s judicial overhaul went ahead. But now that the law has been passed, military officials and experts say it will take time to test the sincerity of those warnings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Takes His Battle for Democracy Case by Case
description: President Biden’s decisions on when to speak out forcefully for democracy can prove tricky.
content: President Biden has made it his mission to wage what he momentously calls “the battle between democracy and autocracy.” But what to do when the ones he believes are undermining democracy are friends?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Rosenthal
title: Your Exorbitant Medical Bill, Brought to You by the Latest Hospital Merger
description: Undoing hospital monopolies may be a lost cause.
content: When Mark Finney moved to southwestern Virginia with his young family a decade ago, there were different hospital systems and a range of independent doctors to choose from.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: How Israel’s Supreme Court Might React to the Challenge to Its Power
description: The court could strike down the law passed on Monday that seeks to curb its power. Or it might narrowly interpret it. Or it might simply put off any decision.
content: As protesters continue to pour into the streets throughout Israel, condemning a bill passed on Monday by the right-wing government to blunt the power of the country’s judiciary, the Israeli Supreme Court faces a momentous decision: How should it respond to a challenge to its own power?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Kreiner
title: Lessons on Leadership From a Barbarian King
description: In “Theoderic the Great,” the historian Hans-Ulrich Wiemer dissects the rule of the Goth king who nurtured Roman culture and impressed Machiavelli.
content: Some haters remember Theoderic the Great for a single event. In the 520s, the Goth king of Italy, paranoid about a conspiracy in the Roman Senate, committed the “original sin” of executing the Roman aristocrat Anicius Manlius Severinus Boethius.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: How to Discuss Pain With Your Doctor
description: And ways to advocate for yourself if you’re being ignored.
content: The women had heard that IVF would be hard, but many of them were in shock at how painful the procedure was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Greta Gerwig on the Blockbuster ‘Barbie’ Opening (and How She Got Away With It)
description: “I think it was a particular ripple in the universe that allowed it to happen,” the director said on Tuesday of her highly anticipated movie making a staggering $162 million in its first weekend.
content: It’s a “Barbie” world. We’re all just living in it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil and Helene Cooper
title: A former U.S. Marine who was freed in a prisoner swap was injured while fighting in Ukraine, the State Department said.
description: Trevor Reed’s condition was not immediately clear. His decision to return to the region and volunteer to fight for Ukraine created some “exasperation” within the Biden administration, an administration official said.
content: Trevor Reed, the former U.S. Marine who was detained in Russia for nearly three years and later freed in a prisoner swap, was injured while fighting in Ukraine, the State Department said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 25, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, July 25, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about a tornado that damaged a Pfizer drug manufacturing site misstated which drugs are made at the Rocky Mount Pfizer site. They do not include the sedative propofol and the antibiotic vancomycin. The article also misstated who had traveled to the site to assess the damage. Only Pfizer officials were there, not Food and Drug Administration staff.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Answers Listener Questions on Biden, Psychedelics, His New Book and More
description: The July 25, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode where Klein answers listeners’ questions. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: In Search of New York City’s Most Elusive Hot Dog
description: Skippy’s on Staten Island is worth the hunt.
content: My sister sent me a TikTok in which the comedian Matt Bellassai shares his hourslong journey to New York City’s last Dairy Queen, on Staten Island, only to find that it’s closed. This week, I found myself in a similar situation: I drove to Staten Island on a Monday in search of the family-owned Skippy’s Hot Dog Truck, a local legend that has posted up on Hylan Boulevard for 61 years. After circling the block for 30 minutes and chatting with a group of locals, I had to admit defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Thousands of demonstrators blocked roads in Jerusalem, Tel Aviv and around Israel in protest last night, after the Parliament passed a law limiting the Supreme Court’s ability to overturn decisions made by government ministers. Some demonstrators yelled, “For shame,” as the police fired water cannons at them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: Once Praised, Jails Chief Draws Ire Over Lack of Transparency on Rikers
description: Under pressure to stem violence in New York City jails, the commissioner, Louis A. Molina, has angered federal officials by withholding information on sensitive investigations.
content: As pressure mounted earlier this year to show improvements in New York City’s troubled jails system, its commissioner, Louis A. Molina, made a major change in how the agency responds to violent incidents and staff misconduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha C. White
title: In Remote Work Era, Hotel Operators Make a Bet on Longer Stays
description: Extended-stay hotels, which are cheaper to build and operate than their full-service counterparts, are also appealing to work crews on road, green energy and other infrastructure projects.
content: As a road warrior for 35 years, Tanna Pearman has crisscrossed the country, staying at luxury hotels and roadside motels. Her least favorite are boxy convention hotels with cavernous lobbies that are easy to get lost in. But at the top of her list is extended-stay lodging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Breakaway Groups
description: Gary Larson and Doug Peterson make perfect pairs in their collaboration debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Jill Biden Takes the 2024 Campaign to Paris in Another Overseas Appeal
description: As the United States officially rejoined UNESCO, the first lady delivered what sounded like a campaign message, saying the president had rebuilt bonds that frayed under his predecessor.
content: At first glance, Jill Biden’s work on her trips overseas appears to be rooted in the traditional duties of first ladies: She has cheered on American Olympians in Tokyo, made a secret trip to Ukraine to meet with the country’s first lady and attended the royal wedding of the crown prince of Jordan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander C. Karp
title: Our Oppenheimer Moment: The Creation of A.I. Weapons
description: Why the United States should lead the development of A.I. technology, including for military applications.
content: In 1942, J. Robert Oppenheimer, the son of a painter and a textile importer, was appointed to lead Project Y, the military effort established by the Manhattan Project to develop nuclear weapons. Oppenheimer and his colleagues worked in secret at a remote laboratory in New Mexico to discover methods for purifying uranium and ultimately to design and build working atomic bombs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Snap’s Sales Fall for the Second Time in a Row
description: The parent of Snapchat has grappled with an ad slump and the challenges of being a smaller social media company in an intensely competitive environment.
content: Snap, the parent company of Snapchat, reported its second straight decline in quarterly sales on Tuesday as it continued to struggle with bringing in more advertising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: ‘Attenzione, Pickpocket!’ A TikTok Star Watches Out for Tourists in Italy
description: Monica Poli has spent years patrolling the streets of Venice. Now she’s famous on social media. Well, at least her voice is.
content: You probably don’t know Monica Poli’s face, but you might recognize her voice. Deep, booming and coming from your phone during a late-night TikTok scroll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Alphabet Steams Past Ad Worries, Fueled by Google’s Search Engine
description: Despite concerns of a shaky ad market and growing competition in A.I., Google’s bounce forward in the second quarter was aided by accelerating revenue from its search engine and the video platform YouTube.
content: Alphabet, Google’s parent company, gained ground in its most recent quarter against several of its lingering challenges, according to financial results released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: A Federal Judge Blocked Biden’s Immigration Restrictions
description: Also, Harvard’s legacy admissions come under scrutiny. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: The number of migrants apprehended at the southern U.S. border has plummeted over the past two months, in spite of expectations of a big influx after the lifting of Title 42 in May. Perhaps the biggest reason for the drop, officials say, is that President Biden’s stringent new asylum rules have effectively turned migrants away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Warming Could Push the Atlantic Past a ‘Tipping Point’ This Century
description: The system of ocean currents that regulates the climate for a swath of the planet could collapse sooner than expected, a new analysis found.
content: The last time there was a major slowdown in the mighty network of ocean currents that shapes the climate around the North Atlantic, it seems to have plunged Europe into a deep cold for over a millennium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: I Saw ‘Barbie’ With Susan Faludi, and She Has a Theory About It
description: The author of “Backlash” thinks Greta Gerwig’s film is more than a delight.
content: Susan Faludi suggested we show up to the “Barbie” movie in a pink Corvette, but unfortunately, the only car available was a pickup truck. So that was how one of the world’s leading feminists and I showed up to her local mall: in a 2002 black Toyota Tacoma, with tickets to Auditorium 2 for “Barbie.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Israel’s Government Moves to Weaken Judges, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Biden Creates Monument to Emmett Till Amid Fights Over Black History
description: The murder of 14-year-old Emmett Till and the activism of his grieving mother helped galvanize the civil rights movement in America.
content: In 1955, the mother of Emmett Till wrote to President Dwight D. Eisenhower pleading for justice for her 14-year-old son, whose murder galvanized the civil rights movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s New Central Banker Once Fixed a Crisis. He May Need to Again.
description: Pan Gongsheng, who was named governor of the People’s Bank of China after overseeing $3 trillion in reserves, stopped a currency plunge in 2016.
content: For nearly eight years Pan Gongsheng has overseen one of the world’s biggest pots of money: China’s $3 trillion in foreign currency reserves. Now he will run the country’s central bank, playing an even more powerful role in the Chinese economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Sends More Weapons to Kyiv Amid Slow Counteroffensive
description: The package, which includes artillery, air defenses and mine-clearing equipment, will help replenish Ukrainian forces advance through dense Russian minefields and other defenses.
content: U.S. officials said on Tuesday that the Biden administration was sending up to $400 million in additional military aid to Ukraine, including artillery, air defenses and mine-clearing equipment, in an effort to help replenish Kyiv’s forces as their counteroffensive grinds on.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Exclamatory Playlist!
description: Wham! Neu! “Oh! Darling” and more artists and songs that make a statement.
content: If you’re looking for something light, fun and full of ridiculous ’80s fashion, I can’t recommend the new Netflix documentary about the pop group Wham! enough — it’s basically the documentary equivalent of a beach read.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Israel’s New Judicial Law Could Threaten Attorney General’s Role
description: The law could make it easier for the government to fire the embattled official, Gali Baharav-Miara, who has criticized Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s judicial overhaul.
content: Critics of the right-wing Israeli government’s new judicial law fear it could threaten a key state watchdog: the attorney general, Gali Baharav-Miara.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Persuasion, Patience and Many Permits Brought Buddhist Relics to the Met
description: How the museum and Indian institutions overcame eight years of physical and diplomatic challenges to bring 125 rare Buddhist art works to New York.
content: What weighs more than 4,000 pounds, lives on a remote island and can only travel by boat during India’s dry seasons? Answer: five ancient limestone sculptures that needed to somehow arrive in New York — via crate, pontoon barge, ferry over the Krishna River and truck to an airport in Hyderabad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Israel’s Self-Inflicted Wound
description: A statesman sacrifices himself for his nation. A demagogue sacrifices his nation for himself.
content: On Monday, the American Anthropological Association approved a resolution boycotting Israeli academic institutions. It’s the sort of illiberal and curiously targeted gesture — the association has confirmed to The Times that it has no similar boycott against any other country’s academic institutions, not even Russia’s — that on any other day would have infuriated me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Maddie McGarvey
title: Could the Next Pandemic Start at the County Fair?
description: Since 2011, there have been more human swine flu cases reported in the United States than anywhere else in the world. Most have occurred at farm-animal showcases.
content: It was showtime at the youth swine exhibition, and the pig barn was bustling. The competitors, ages 3 to 21, were practicing their walks for the show ring and brushing pig bristles into place. Parents were braiding children’s hair, adding ribbons and pig-shaped barrettes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: ‘My Heart Was Racing’: The Week 5 Winner of Our Summer Reading Contest
description: Yugottam Koirala, 18, a student from Nepal, writes about what Himalayan glacier loss could mean for his country.
content: Our annual Summer Reading Contest invites teenagers around the world to tell us what New York Times pieces get their attention and why. This week, the midpoint of our 10-week challenge, we received 938 entries. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Yugottam Koirala, as well as to the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Tornado at Pfizer Warehouse Likely to Worsen Shortage of Surgical Drugs
description: A tornado that damaged a Pfizer plant in North Carolina will likely limit supplies of pain relievers used in surgery and other critical-care drugs.
content: A tornado that ripped apart a vast Pfizer drug warehouse in North Carolina last week will probably lead to disrupted supplies of crucial drugs used in surgery and critical care, according to estimates made by an independent nonprofit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Involved in Car Crash in Tennessee; He Is Unhurt
description: The crash occurred in Chattanooga as Mr. DeSantis and his team were traveling to a fund-raiser there, a spokesman said.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida was involved in a car crash in Chattanooga, Tenn., on his way to a fund-raiser there on Tuesday, according to his spokesman, who added that Mr. DeSantis was unhurt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Patricia Cohen
title: Russian Attack Threatens Even Alternative Routes for Ukrainian Grain
description: The attack on a grain hangar on the Danube River, an alternative export route that has become an economic lifeline, complicates Ukraine’s efforts to export its grain.
content: For shipping companies looking for a way to bring Ukrainian grain to global markets, the options keep dwindling, escalating a trade crisis that is expected to add pressure on global food prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Cuts Campaign Staff by Over a Third, Aiming to Rein In Costs
description: His presidential campaign, facing questions from allies and donors about the strength of his candidacy, has now eliminated the jobs of 38 aides this month.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is sharply cutting the size of his presidential campaign staff, reducing by more than one-third a payroll that had swelled to more than 90 people in his first two months as a candidate, according to four people with knowledge of the decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: 8 Men Are Convicted in 2016 Terrorist Bombings in Brussels
description: The series of attacks was the deadliest such assault in Belgian history. Six of the accused had already been convicted over terrorist attacks in Paris the previous year.
content: Eight men were found guilty on Tuesday of having organized a series of bombings in Brussels in March 2016 that amounted to the deadliest terrorist assault in Belgium’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M.’s Electric Vehicle Rollout Delayed by Slow Battery Production
description: The company is earning big profits on gasoline cars and trucks but is struggling to catch up to Tesla in the fastest-growing segment of the auto market.
content: General Motors is investing tens of billions of dollars to produce new electric vehicles and, it hopes, catch up to Tesla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Senate Committee Presses Leon Black on Epstein Tax Advice
description: The billionaire investor paid Jeffrey Epstein $158 million for tax and estate planning services. Lawmakers want to know if the fees should have been taxed as a gift.
content: A Senate committee is investigating whether $158 million that the billionaire investor Leon Black paid the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein for tax and estate planning services should have been classified as a gift, as part of a broader inquiry into tax-avoidance schemes by ultrawealthy individuals, according to a letter sent by the committee to Mr. Black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Three Convicted in 1997 Murder Seek New Trial
description: Derrick Chappell, Morton Johnson and Samuel Grasty say new DNA evidence shows that an unidentified attacker killed Henrietta Nickens, 70, in Chester, Pa. Prosecutors oppose the request.
content: Mother and daughter spent their last night together playing cards. The next afternoon, the daughter, Carlotta Nickens, stopped by her mother’s apartment and found her face down in the hallway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Anemona Hartocollis
title: Education Dept. Opens Civil Rights Inquiry Into Harvard’s Legacy Admissions
description: An inquiry into admissions preference for family of alumni and donors began after the Supreme Court’s decision last month limiting affirmative action.
content: The Education Department has opened a civil rights investigation into Harvard University’s legacy admissions policy, inserting the federal government directly into a fierce national debate about wealth, privilege and race after the Supreme Court gutted the use of affirmative action in higher education.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: E.R. Mystery? Ask Dr. Chatbot for a Diagnosis.
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 25, 2023.
content: “Part of learning is the struggle. If you outsource learning to GPT, that struggle is gone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: China has replaced its foreign minister, the world gets some good economic news, Israel faces a cliffhanger.
content: Qin Gang was abruptly removed as China’s foreign minister after disappearing from public view for 30 days. The move ended the career of a diplomat who had been one of President Xi Jinping’s most trusted rising stars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Doctor Who Abused Women Sentenced to 20 Years Imprisonment
description: Robert A. Hadden, a gynecologist, was convicted of luring women across state lines to appointments in Manhattan where he abused them.
content: A former Manhattan gynecologist was sentenced to 20 years in prison in federal court on Tuesday after being convicted of inducing four patients to cross state lines for examinations during which he sexually assaulted them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Quammen
title: The Ongoing Mystery of Covid’s Origin
description: We still don’t know how the pandemic started. Here's what we do know — and why it matters.
content: Where did it come from? More than three years into the pandemic and untold millions of people dead, that question about the Covid-19 coronavirus remains controversial and fraught, with facts sparkling amid a tangle of analyses and hypotheticals like Christmas lights strung on a dark, thorny tree. One school of thought holds that the virus, known to science as SARS-CoV-2, spilled into humans from a nonhuman animal, probably in the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market, a messy emporium in Wuhan, China, brimming with fish, meats and wildlife on sale as food. Another school argues that the virus was laboratory-engineered to infect humans and cause them harm — a bioweapon — and was possibly devised in a “shadow project” sponsored by the People’s Liberation Army of China. A third school, more moderate than the second but also implicating laboratory work, suggests that the virus got into its first human victim by way of an accident at the Wuhan Institute of Virology (W.I.V.), a research complex on the eastern side of the city, maybe after well-meaning but reckless genetic manipulation that made it more dangerous to people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Judge Vacates Bowe Bergdahl’s Conviction and Dishonorable Discharge
description: The Army colonel overseeing the court-martial trial had applied for a job with the Trump-era Justice Department, raising the appearance of bias.
content: A federal judge on Tuesday wiped out the conviction and sentence of Bowe Bergdahl, the former Army sergeant who walked off a base in Afghanistan in 2009 only to be held captive by the Taliban for five years, and whose release in a prisoner swap prompted intense controversy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: discern
description: This word has appeared in 183 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word discern has appeared in 183 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 31 in “Quiet, Please: You Are Not Alone in Your Garden” by Margaret Roach:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Alabama Woman Admits She Lied About Abduction and Report of Wandering Child
description: Carlee Russell, 25, said through a lawyer that she was sorry she had fabricated her disappearance, which captured national attention and prompted a flurry of search efforts.
content: An Alabama woman whose brief disappearance this month drew national attention and prompted sprawling search efforts across the state said through a lawyer on Monday that she had faked the entire ordeal — including her abduction and her claim of seeing a toddler on the side of a road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Eshe Nelson and Jeanna Smialek
title: Global Economy Shows Signs of Resilience Despite Lingering Threats
description: The International Monetary Fund upgraded its global growth forecast for 2023.
content: The world economy is showing signs of resilience this year despite lingering inflation and a sluggish recovery in China, the International Monetary Fund said on Tuesday, raising the odds that a global recession could be avoided barring unexpected crises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Both Sides Plan for Next Battles Over Israel’s Court Overhaul
description: The government’s vote to limit judicial power set off a night of street chaos. More showdowns are expected, but with Parliament about to recess, it is not clear when or in what form.
content: After frenzied days capped by Israeli lawmakers voting to limit judicial power and protesters clashing with police, doctors went on strike on Tuesday, the military tried to stave off resignations and all sides girded for a longer fight over the government’s court overhaul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Ales Pushkin, Dissident Artist in Belarus, Is Dead in Prison at 57
description: A “holy fool,” in his words, he railed against the repressive Lukashenko government, once with a pile of manure. He died under mysterious circumstances.
content: Ales Pushkin, a dissident artist in Belarus whose incendiary work often took aim at the country’s authoritarian leader, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, in one instance with a pile of manure dumped outside the presidential offices in Minsk, has died in prison while serving a five-year sentence. He was 57.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Will Translation Apps Make Learning Foreign Languages Obsolete?
description: And if so, is that really such a disaster?
content: In Europe, nine out of 10 students study a foreign language. In the United States, only one in five do. Between 1997 and 2008, the number of American middle schools offering foreign languages dropped from 75 percent to 58 percent. Between 2009 and 2013, one American college closed its foreign language program; between 2013 and 2017, 651 others did the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Taliban Shut Beauty Salons, One of Afghan Women’s Last Public Spaces
description: Following through on an order that prompted rare protests in the capital, the Taliban said the services of the women-only businesses violated Shariah law.
content: All women’s beauty salons in Afghanistan were set to close on Tuesday, officials said, as part of a Taliban administration announcement early this month that the women-only spaces were forbidden under Shariah law and caused economic hardship for grooms’ families during wedding celebrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Some July Heat: ‘Virtually Impossible’ Without Climate Change, Analysis Finds
description: The latest study from World Weather Attribution scientists predicts that extreme heat waves will return more frequently.
content: Some of the extreme temperatures recorded in the Southwestern United States, southern Europe and northern Mexico at the beginning of the month would have been “virtually impossible” without the influence of human-caused climate change, according to research made public Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What Might a Disaster-Proof House in California Look Like?
description: A conversation with Christopher Flavelle, a New York Times climate reporter who recently wrote about renewed attention on homes that can withstand extreme weather.
content: Record-breaking snowfall. Dangerously high temperatures. Devastating floods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Eileen Sullivan
title: Federal Judge Blocks Biden Administration’s New Asylum Policy
description: Immigrant advocacy groups had challenged the administration’s decision to sharply limit who is allowed to apply for asylum in the United States.
content: A federal judge struck down on Tuesday a stringent new asylum policy that the Biden administration has called crucial to its efforts to curb illegal crossings along the U.S.-Mexico border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Her New Husband Came With a Haussmann-Style Apartment in Paris
description: For two designers living in Brooklyn, meeting and marrying felt like destiny. The renovation of the grand apartment in France followed naturally.
content: By the time Megan Grehl finally met Côme Ménage, it felt as if their relationship was meant to be. Both had studied architecture and urban design internationally, and when Ms. Grehl landed in Shanghai in 2009 to work at the design firm Neri&Hu, she heard stories about Mr. Ménage, who had just left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: What Happened to Japan?
description: And is it relevant to China?
content: I hope that at least some of my readers are too young to remember this, but in the early 1990s many Americans — especially pundits, but also business leaders and a fair share of the general public — were obsessed with the rise of Japan. Two of the best-selling books of 1992 were Michael Crichton’s novel “Rising Sun,” about what he imagined to be the growing, sinister influence of Japanese corporations, and Lester Thurow’s “Head to Head: The Coming Economic Battle Among Japan, Europe and America.” It’s easy to forget now, but I like to remind people how airport bookstores were full of paperbacks with samurai warriors on their covers, purporting to teach you the secrets of Japanese management.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: At Two Summer Theater Festivals, Reassuring Signs of Life
description: The industry is facing challenges, but in western Massachusetts the quality of the works is as rich as ever, our critic writes.
content: Suddenly, out of the darkness, came one of the most thrilling sounds an audience can make: a collective gasp. This is how you know that the crowd is rapt, that the storytelling has taken hold. And so it had the other night during a performance of “Blues for an Alabama Sky” at Barrington Stage Company, where a different plot twist elicited another welcome noise: a mid-scene eruption of delighted applause. Humans can be a lot of fun to see a show with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Wearing Paint Instead of Clothes on the Streets of New York
description: Naked bodies of all shapes and sizes became artists’ canvases at a public art exhibition.
content: Across from a Pret a Manger near Union Square Park, Nicolette Barischoff held still as an artist painted an open blue eye across her sternum on Sunday. It was around 88 degrees and a crowd had assembled around them. But the temperature and the audience did not faze Ms. Barischoff. Nor did the fact that she was naked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Pete Davidson Plans F.D.N.Y. Community Service to Resolve Crash Case
description: The former “Saturday Night Live” cast member faced a reckless driving charge in California. His father, a New York City firefighter, was killed responding to the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
content: Pete Davidson, the comedian, actor and former “Saturday Night Live” cast member, has reached an agreement that allows him to resolve a reckless driving charge in California by doing community service with the New York Fire Department, officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Fauzia
title: The Prize for the Longest Pregnancy in Mammals May Go to This Whale
description: Bowhead whales may carry their babies for as long as 23 months, although more research is needed to confirm the finding.
content: For animals that humans almost drove into extinction, there’s a lot about whales we still don’t know. Consider the bowhead whale in particular.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: After Momentous Vote on Judicial Law, Israel Braces for What’s Next
description: The opposition fears a slow descent toward authoritarianism, while the government is waiting to see how disruptive and prolonged the response will be from its critics.
content: A law passed in Israel’s Parliament on Monday to limit the power of the judiciary left the country with something of a cliffhanger, with the real effects of the government’s move likely to remain unclear for weeks or even months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta and Neil MacFarquhar
title: Putin Plans Trip to China, Another Russian Leader to Visit North Korea
description: The visits reflect Moscow’s ongoing efforts to strengthen ties with Asian allies, given its isolation from the West.
content: As part of Russia’s ongoing efforts to strengthen ties with Asian allies, President Vladimir V. Putin will travel to a conference in China in October, while the defense minister, Sergei K. Shoigu, will join a Chinese delegation at a celebration in North Korea this week, according to Russian state news media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: In Photos: Mass Protests Sweep Israel
description: Political turmoil that has been brewing for months reached a crescendo after Parliament passed a law aimed at curbing the power of the judiciary.
content: Israel’s political turmoil reached a crescendo on Monday night, when thousands of Israelis took to the streets across the country on Monday evening after the right-wing ruling coalition passed the first part of a controversial plan to weaken Israel’s judiciary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova and David Guttenfelder
title: Leaving the Front Line in Ukraine — to Train for the Front Line
description: A grueling obstacle course, a few miles from the fighting with Russia, is a final step in the initiation for Ukrainian marines.
content: Early in the morning they were at their frontline positions, firing artillery at Russian forces. Hours later, wearing the same uniforms and body armor, they passed their final test — an obstacle course — to officially become Ukrainian marines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Friedman, Sophia Alvarez Boyd and Jillian Weinberger
title: ‘Joe Biden May Be the Last Pro-Israel Democratic President’
description: Tom Friedman on what contentious judicial changes mean for the U.S.-Israeli relationship.
content: Despite forceful opposition, Israel’s government passed a judicial reform law that limits the ability of the country’s Supreme Court to overrule the government. In this audio short, our columnist Tom Friedman explains how the new law could destabilize the United States’ relationship with Israel and complicate American interests in the Middle East. “We are in a completely new phase now of relations between America and the Jewish state,” Friedman says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Up in Smoke: Canada’s Outdoor Summer Season
description: Those planning to visit the country’s extensive forests and backcountry have been stymied by the raging wildfires, just as the country’s travel industry was bouncing back.
content: Fishing trips to Canada are a tradition for Jeffrey Hardy and his three friends from Vermont. They have, since 2001, been anglers loyal to Quebec’s northern wilderness, where the walleye are plentiful and the cellphone service is not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: An Investigation Into Mexico’s 43 Missing Students Ends in ‘Falsehoods and Diversions’
description: Members of an international panel said that the Mexican armed forces had repeatedly obstructed their efforts to investigate the 2014 disappearance and that they were leaving the country.
content: A panel of international experts investigating the 2014 abduction of 43 students in southern Mexico said on Tuesday that it was ending its inquiry after being repeatedly lied to and misled by the Mexican armed forces about their role in the crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stella Bugbee
title: X: The Brand, the Generation and Elon Musk
description: One little letter, so much baggage.
content: The letter has its obvious appeals. X is a versatile shape — one of the few capital letters to remain symmetrical whether bisected vertically or horizontally (the others: H, O and I). It’s legible no matter how you flip it. It signals a stop. A mark on a map. A movie too outrageous to give a rating. It’s the stuff of revolutionaries (Malcolm X) and punks (X, the band). It stands in for a kiss, and represents an unknown quantity in mathematics. XXX is porn — the first true currency of the internet. X can be the hidden conspiracy of “The X-Files,” or the shorthand for the drug Ecstasy, popular with ravers in the ’90s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Trump to Return Ancient Coins and Lamps to Israel’s Antiquities Agency
description: The items have been at former President Donald J. Trump’s home in Florida since 2021, when they were presented to him during a Hanukkah celebration.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump will return a set of ancient coins and ceramic oil lamps to Israel’s government after reports last week that Israeli officials were pressing to retrieve them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Venice Film Festival Lineup Largely Unscathed by Hollywood Strikes
description: Movies from Bradley Cooper, Sofia Coppola and Ava DuVernay will debut at this year’s event, despite the industry shutdown.
content: The Hollywood strikes have halted production on major movies, pushed back release dates and stopped actors appearing on red carpets. But on Tuesday, the organizers of the Venice Film Festival said this year’s event would be relatively unscathed by the turmoil, and announced a star-studded lineup.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Gay, Dominant, Single, White, Female’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: We called Dad “The Answerman.” He seemed to know the answer to every question. Mom accused him of thinking he knew more than God, which was funny since my father was agnostic. “I guess that makes me God’s wife,” she would say. She even went so far as to get a vanity license plate “GDSWF” (“God’s wife”). When she got it, she hadn’t considered any alternative meanings for “GDSWF,” like “Gay, Dominant, Single, White, Female.” When the honks and waves started coming, Mom laughed and waved back, celebrating the diversity of humankind, just as God’s wife would. — Caren Albers
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: One-Pan Zucchini-Pesto Orzo With a Bright Caprese Topping
description: Marinated mozzarella and cherry tomatoes top herby orzo loaded with sautéed zucchini and onions.
content: If you only master two cooking fundamentals this summer, let it be these: cooking meat, fish, tofu and vegetables in utterly simple ways and making an easy sauce to go with them. Yewande Komolafe’s steak recipe brings both skills together in one dish, giving you instructions for grilling the meat and blending up a sauce of scallions, garlic, parsley and chiles. Likewise, Ali Slagle’s baked BBQ chicken comes down to properly roasting bone-in chicken leg quarters in a sticky-sweet blanket of barbecue sauce. Melissa Clark’s new orzo recipe leans on golden brown sautéed zucchini and pesto for instantaneous flavor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Man Sentenced to 30 Months in Death of ‘The Wire’ Actor
description: Carlos Macci, 72, was part of a crew that sold Michael K. Williams fentanyl-laced heroin that killed him in 2021.
content: Carlos Macci spent decades struggling with addiction, selling heroin and fentanyl not to make money but to ease his own cravings, according to court records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Jim Gaffigan’s Quintessentially American Comedy Gets Darker and Better
description: He’ll still joke about fast food. But on “Dark Pale,” his 10th stand-up special, his evolution as a comedian is apparent.
content: Have we gotten Jim Gaffigan wrong all along?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: A Postcard to Chinatown, Mailed from the Lower East Side
description: Potluck Club looks at the old neighborhood, and its dishes, through the eyes of a younger generation who grew up there.
content: Potluck Club opened last summer on Chrystie Street on the Lower East Side — outside the old boundaries of Chinatown, in an area where younger Chinese businesses sidle up against tattoo parlors, oyster bars and candlelit cocktail lounges with disguised speakeasy entrances. It’s a perfect location for a neo-Cantonese restaurant that looks at Chinatown traditions from a slight distance, through the eyes of young people who grew up eating in and around the neighborhood but have spent most of their adult lives in other places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gonzalez and José A. Alvarado Jr
title: Vital Places of Refuge in the Bronx, Community Gardens Gain Recognition
description: Lawmakers in Albany voted to designate community gardens statewide as crucial to the urban environment, especially in the fight against climate change. The bill awaits the governor’s signature but the role of these gardens stretches back decades.
content: Sheryll Durrant came from a family of farmers in Jamaica and embarked on a career in corporate marketing. But after the 2008 financial meltdown, she reconsidered her life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: We Know What’s Causing This Heat
description: It’s still very hot, and scientists are getting better at telling us why.
content: Some of the searing temperatures that scorched the United States, Mexico, Europe and China this month would not have happened without human-caused climate change, my colleague Delger Erdenesanaa reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli, Billy Witz and Gina Kolata
title: Bronny James, Son of LeBron James, Is Stable After Cardiac Arrest
description: Bronny, a basketball recruit at the University of Southern California, was stricken during a practice on Monday. He is out of intensive care and in stable condition, his family said.
content: LeBron James Jr., the son of the N.B.A. star LeBron James, suffered a cardiac arrest while practicing at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles on Monday and was taken to the hospital for treatment in the intensive care unit, according to a statement from a spokesman for LeBron James and his wife, Savannah. The younger James, known as Bronny, is now in stable condition and no longer in the I.C.U., the statement said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Wrestling With His Past. And an Animatronic Shark.
description: Ian Shaw plays his father, Robert Shaw, in “The Shark Is Broken,” a comedy based on the troubled production of the 1975 film “Jaws.”
content: In a rehearsal space near Times Square, Ian Shaw was talking about the strange and solemn task of portraying his own father in a Broadway play that he had co-written.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Israel’s Political Crisis
description: Now, political leaders will be more powerful and judges less so.
content: In their details, the judicial changes that Israel’s Parliament passed yesterday sound like something that liberals in the U.S. and democracy advocates around the world might support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachid Sekkai and Vivian Yee
title: 34 Killed in Algerian Wildfires as Heat Waves Parch Mediterranean Region
description: Algeria’s government said that 10 of the dead were soldiers who were trying to rescue people from the fires, which have raged for days in a forested coastal region.
content: Wildfires devouring swaths of Algeria’s Mediterranean coast have killed 34 people over two days, the Algerian authorities said on Tuesday, as an extreme heat wave sears North Africa, Southern Europe and the sea between them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Powerful Typhoon Grazes the Philippines on Its Way to China
description: Typhoon Doksuri, which had packed winds equivalent to those of a Category 4 hurricane, is expected to hit China later this week. It also threatens Taiwan.
content: Typhoon Doksuri, a tropical cyclone moving through the Pacific Ocean with wind speeds equivalent to those of a Category 4 hurricane, grazed the northern Philippines on Wednesday morning and was expected to pass near Taiwan before making landfall in China later this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Will Reid, Clare Toeniskoetter, Rob Szypko, M.J. Davis Lin, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Russia’s Newest Target: The Global Food Supply
description: What will a breakdown in food shipments from Ukraine mean for the war and the world?
content: When Russia invaded Ukraine, it put the global food supply at risk — until the two countries struck an unusual deal to keep shipments flowing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Psychedelic Therapy, Threads vs. Twitter, My New Book and More
description: Ezra Klein answers listeners’ questions.
content: As I head into a three-month book leave, I wanted to take some time to address a wide array of listeners’ questions. My column editor, Aaron Retica, joins me for a conversation that ranges from the content of my forthcoming book and President Biden’s climate record to the simulation hypothesis and legalized psychedelic therapy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Zernike
title: Ohio Will Vote on Abortion Rights
description: Backers of a proposal to establish a right to abortion in the Ohio Constitution submitted enough valid signatures to put the question on the November ballot.
content: Ohio voters will decide in November whether to amend their state Constitution to establish a right to abortion, after state officials said on Tuesday that proponents had submitted over 495,000 valid signatures from voters, more than enough to put the question on the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Microsoft Revenue Up 8% to $56.2 Billion in Latest Quarter
description: The company’s profit topped $20 billion as it pointed to early interest in its artificial intelligence products.
content: Microsoft reported record sales and profits on Tuesday, as it shook off recession fears and began seeing the early impacts of its investments in generative artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Israel Divided Against Itself
description: Readers react to the turmoil over the Supreme Court overhaul. Also: Ron DeSantis and Black history in Florida; legacy admissions; prostitution.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Are Tech Companies Liable for Buffalo’s Racist Massacre? Families Say Yes.
description: Relatives of victims say social media platforms are responsible for radicalizing the killer, but two lawsuits that they’ve filed face tough odds.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at whether tech companies like Google and Meta were to blame for last year’s racist massacre in Buffalo, as the families of some victims say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: A Somber Mood Settles Over Israel’s Antigovernment Protesters
description: After months of defiance, there was defeat. The right-wing government’s success in passing a law that limits the power of the Supreme Court was a gut punch to the largely liberal and secular opposition.
content: The roads around the Parliament and Supreme Court in Jerusalem were nearly deserted on Tuesday morning after chaotic late-night scenes of protesters facing off against police on horseback and armed with water cannons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: The 3 Sites That Will Honor Emmett Till and His Mother
description: These locations, including the area where Emmett Till's body was found, will established as national monuments.
content: These locations, including the area where Emmett Till's body was found, will established as national monuments.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Their Home Away From Brooklyn: a Paris Pied-à-Terre
description: For two designers, meeting and marrying felt like destiny. The renovation of the grand apartment in France followed naturally.
content: For two designers, meeting and marrying felt like destiny. The renovation of the grand apartment in France followed naturally.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Angela Moore Got Retirement Ready
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Signs Proclamation to Create Emmett Till Monument
description: The national monument will honor Emmett Till, the Black teenager who was abducted and killed by white supremacists in 1955, and his mother, Mamie Till-Mobley.
content: The national monument will honor Emmett Till, the Black teenager who was abducted and killed by white supremacists in 1955, and his mother, Mamie Till-Mobley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dream Hampton
title: Freshwater
description: Dream Hampton explores water as a force of harmony and devastation as climate change affects her home city of Detroit.
content: Dream Hampton explores water as a force of harmony and devastation as climate change affects her home city of Detroit.
source.name: The New York Times
